description: A handful of small water-soluble white crystals with watery metallic odor, historically used for many different purposes.  Also known as potash alum and potassium aluminum sulfate; often called simply alum, as it's the most important member of the generic class of compounds called alums.
//: Useless and unobtainable at the moment.  TODO: either add uses or remove if none are found.

description: A handful of powdered colorful cloth dye, which can be used to dye many fabrics if combined with water and some mordant.
//: Useless and unobtainable at the moment.  TODO: either add uses or remove if none are found.

description: A handful of white, odorless, strongly hygroscopic powder with an extremely salty taste.  Often used as a de-icing agent or as desiccant.
A handful of white, odorless, hygroscopic powder.  Often used as a cleansing agent and for glass manufacturing, among other things.  Also known as sodium carbonate or soda ash.
A handful of white, odorless powder with a slightly salty alkaline taste.  Often used in baking as a leavening agent, and has many other niche uses.  Also known as sodium bicarbonate.
Elemental mercury, unique in that it is a liquid under normal temperatures and pressures.  Known for its use in thermometers.

A handful of gray powder that is highly sensitive to friction, heat, and shock.  Often used as a primary explosive, and historically in percussion caps and primers for self-contained firearm ammunition.
Chunks of sodium, a highly reactive soft gray metal, that are immersed in anhydrous mineral oil to prevent them from oxidizing in air during storage.
//: Currently represented as liquid due to the requirement of storing metallic sodium in specific conditions.  Freezing point (of a mineral oil, in this case) is a guess.

description: A chunk of potassium, a highly reactive soft gray metal, immersed in anhydrous mineral oil to prevent it from oxidizing in the air during storage.
A handful of white powder that is used in detonators to detonate secondary explosives.  It replaced mercury fulminate in modern ammunition primers.
